urn:contentItem:5JCV-9R51-JBKR-G1WG-00000-00Apple puts itself above the law; Controversy highlights big tech's self-righteous arrogance2016-03-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. FP2Apple puts itself above the law; Controversy highlights big tech's self-righteous arroganceDiane FrancisFinancial Post

It seems Americans trust their tech companies - led by Apple Inc.- to protect their privacy.

They shouldn't. This trust factor showed up in a recent poll taken following the highly publicized legal battle between Apple and the U.S. Justice Department began.

Justice officials asked Apple to de-encrypt an iPhone used by a terrorist. Apple has refused to do so, becoming a Silicon Valley hero, billing itself as a defender of the private sector and privacy.

The tussle ended, perhaps temporarily, when Justice officials announced this week that a hacker has approached them who knows how to de-encrypt the phone.

I hope it works because it would serve Apple right. The company's stance was not heroic, it was commercial based on marketing promises that its phones were secure and no one could ever get into one.

Now Apple not only looks like a bad corporate citizen for balking at helping a terrorist investigation, but its brand will be harmed after the phone is hacked.

The best solution would have been a compromise: Apple should have made a deal with Justice in the face of evidence of wrongdoing and the government could have avoided hiring someone to do something "illegal."

Most people would agree that public interest trumps commercial or privacy concerns, especially involving terrorism. I'm sure a poll would show that Apple's customers are more frightened of terrorist mayhem than of getting hacked by some identity thief or the NSA.

In essence, Apple has put itself - and its profits - above the law.

Such a position, by the way, is nothing new in Silicon Valley. Big Tech is as powerful and arrogant as Big Oil. This is because they are collectively more influential and richer than most nation-states. The big four - Apple, Alphabet/Google, Amazon and Facebook - have a combined market capitalization value of US$1.68 trillion.

And unlike Big Oil or Big Pharma or Big Banks, they are more self-righteous even though they have not exactly been exemplary corporate citizens.

Lest we forget, Google took the media's content without paying for it, then took all the advertisers without sharing the profits. This has created a gaping hole in the Fourth Estate that continues to widen, leaving democracies and the public shortchanged in terms of coverage, fact-checking and political accountability.

Only one media mogul, Rupert Murdoch, sued over this, but they all should have and now it's too late.

Big Tech has also been as aggressive and rapacious as other sectors. It has shopped the world for workers, suppliers and tax breaks. It gives enormous campaign contributions. It employs armies of lobbyists and lawyers to fight anti-competitive practices and taxation. Apple, and others, outsourced manufacturing to a Taiwanese company that exploited millions of Chinese workers. Sometimes, suicide nets were strung around worker dormitories after dozens threw themselves off rooftops because of working conditions and pay scales. Now the company is robotizing its factories to phase out human workers.

Others - like Silicon Valley darlings Uber and Airbnb - have flouted laws, regulations, licensing requirements, taxes, insurance requirements in order to provide services that pose a risk to public safety.

Both have become embroiled in battles around the world over injuries, damages and legalities. Uber should only deal with licensed and trained drivers and Airbnb should pay hotel taxes, accept liability for damages or violence and be responsible for screening both renters and rentees.

Instead, Big Tech remains steadfastly stubborn and self-righteous. Yes, they are smart; yes, they are successful; yes, they are improving the world. But they creating socio-economic problems for which they will be unwilling to compensate society.

The biggest issue will occur when automation, robots and Artificial Intelligence begin to destroy or degrade at least half of the jobs in the economy. Will Big Tech compensate and retrain workers? Will politicians on their payroll demand this?

The Apple controversy is a peek into this Brave New World. It's downright shocking that a company would refuse to co-operate with law-enforcement officials. But given Big Tech's attitude it shouldn't surprise.

The big four - Apple, Alphabet/Google, Amazon and Facebook - have a combined market capitalization value of US$1.68 trillion.

And unlike Big Oil or Big Pharma or Big Banks, they are more self-righteous even though they have not exactly been exemplary corporate citizens.

Lest we forget, Google took the media's content without paying for it, then took all the advertisers without sharing the profits. This has created a gaping hole in the Fourth Estate that continues to widen, leaving democracies and the public shortchanged in terms of coverage, fact-checking and political accountability.

Only one media mogul, Rupert Murdoch, sued over this, but they all should have and now it's too late.

Big Tech has also been as aggressive and rapacious as other sectors. It has shopped the world for workers, suppliers and tax breaks. It gives enormous campaign contributions. It employs armies of lobbyists and lawyers to fight anti-competitive practices and taxation. Apple, and others, outsourced manufacturing to a Taiwanese company that exploited millions of Chinese workers. Sometimes, suicide nets were strung around worker dormitories after dozens threw themselves off rooftops because of working conditions and pay scales. Now the company is robotizing its factories to phase out human workers.

Others - like Silicon Valley darlings Uber and Airbnb - have flouted laws, regulations, licensing requirements, taxes, insurance requirements in order to provide services that pose a risk to public safety.

Both have become embroiled in battles around the world over injuries, damages and legalities. Uber should only deal with licensed and trained drivers and Airbnb should pay hotel taxes, accept liability for damages or violence and be responsible for screening both renters and rentees.

Instead, Big Tech remains steadfastly stubborn and self-righteous. Yes, they are smart; yes, they are successful; yes, they are improving the world. But they creating socio-economic problems for which they will be unwilling to compensate society.

The biggest issue will occur when automation, robots and Artificial Intelligence begin to destroy or degrade at least half of the jobs in the economy. Will Big Tech compensate and retrain workers? Will politicians on their payroll demand this?

The Apple controversy is a peek into this Brave New World. It's downright shocking that a company would refuse to co-operate with law-enforcement officials. But given Big Tech's attitude it shouldn't surprise.

urn:contentItem:5X3S-0HP1-JCBB-K17P-00000-00Apple Puts Up Fight, But FANG Internet Giants Are MIA In Stock Market Rally2019-09-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:36ZLexisNexisRESEARCHApple Puts Up Fight, But FANG Internet Giants Are MIA In Stock Market RallyED CARSON

https://www.investors.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/STOCK-apple-092019-shutter.jpg

The stock market rally has made impressive gains in 2019 but many of the tech giants have struggled. Even as Apple stock shows some fight, Facebook stock, Amazon stock, Netflix stock and Google stock have been MIA.

A growing number of government Big Tech probes are underway vs. Facebook, Amazon.com, Google-parent Alphabet and, to a lesser extent, Apple. Netflix faces imminent competition from Disney+ and Apple TV+, along with the existing Amazon Prime Video and several other looming rivals.

Netflix stock is at eight-month lows. Facebook stock and Amazon stock are hitting resistance at their 50-day moving averages. Google stock is moving toward a new buy point. But the for the FANG stocks ranges from lackluster to seriously lagging. Apple stock, by contrast, has been testing a with its RS line at 2019 highs.

FANG Stocks Are MIA In 2019 Stock Market Rally

The stock market rally began 2019 with a powerful rally in software and other growth names. In recent weeks, growth stocks have tumbled while value plays move forward. But through it all, internet giants Facebook, Amazon, Netflix and Google are MIA. Google stock hit a record high in late April, then immediately crashed on earnings. Facebook stock and Amazon stock broke out in early July, but then sold off on earnings later this month.

After running up in early January, Netflix stock slightly lagged the S&P 500 for several months. Shares plunged on July 18 after Netflix reported a rare decline in U.S. subscribers. Shares have continued to slide.

The relative strength line, which compares a stock's performance vs. the S&P 500 index, is a great way to identify stock market winners and laggards. The RS line for Facebook stock is holding at a three-month low. It's at a six-month low for AMZN stock. The relative strength line for NFLX stock recently hit a 20-month low.

GOOGL stock is still working on a buy point from a base. The RS line for Google stock is at the high of the handle, though it's well below the consolidation peak or the July 2018 all-time best.

FANG Stock Woes: Competition Probes Vs. Competition

The regulatory Big Tech probes of Facebook, Amazon, Google and, in some cases, Apple, generally focus on their dominance of online platforms. Those include probes or reviews by the Justice Department, various other federal agencies, at least two major multistate probes as well as various congressional hearings. Several lawmakers, including rising Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren, have called for breaking up some or all of the internet giants.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg met privately with several lawmakers and President Donald Trump last week.

Meanwhile, growth prospects for FANG stocks have cooled. Facebook earnings are expected to rebound in 2020, but much of that reflects big legal charges weighing on EPS this year. Amazon sales growth continues to slow, even with Amazon Web Services and fast-growing advertising revenue offsetting decelerating core e-commerce operations.

Netflix stock doesn't face antitrust concerns. Instead, it faces huge competition from Disney+ and other existing or future streaming networks, including a cheap $4.99 offering from Apple TV+. Keep in mind that while Netflix has reported adjusted earnings for several years, it's still burning huge amounts of cash. Deep-pocketed competitors like Walt Disney, Apple, Comcast and more can afford to run losses for years.

With U.S. growth prospects seeming capped, Netflix is counting on international expansion. But in much of the world Netflix charges far less for subscriptions. And it must spend on local content for local markets.

Apple Stock

Apple stock has been bouncing back and forth with a 221.41 buy point from a . Shares fell 1.5% to 217.73 on Friday, in part due to China trade war headlines. The RS line for AAPL stock recently hit 2019 highs. With many of the software and other high P-E leaders damaged, Apple stock's relative strength vs. the "best stocks" has improved significantly.

On a longer-term basis, Apple stock hasn't really outperformed the S&P since 2012.

New Friday. The new, cheaper base model handset may appeal to Chinese consumers. Next year's Apple iPhones should have 5G capability.

Why Apple Stock, FANG Stocks Matter

Apple and the FANG stocks may never again be the massive market leaders that they were for much of the past decade. But they could still go on decent runs. Even if CAN SLIM investors look for stronger performers, modest contributions from Apple stock, Amazon stock and the other internet giants could still fuel the broader market. Apple has a $1 trillion valuation. The FANG stocks have roughly a $2.4 trillion valuation. Netflix stock may be the weakest link, but it's also the smallest FANG at $118.5 billion, giving it room grow if it can sustain vs. rivals.

urn:contentItem:60MP-VYT1-DXXD-70NB-00000-00Apple Reaches $2 Trillion Market Value As Big Tech Earnings Surge2020-08-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:36ZLexisNexisTECHApple Reaches $2 Trillion Market Value As Big Tech Earnings SurgeVarun HukeriReportervarun@dailycaller.com

Link to Image

Apple became the first American company to reach a market value of $2 trillion Wednesday after its share price hit $467.77 in early stock market trading.

The tech giant's share price has increased roughly 60% year to date despite the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic, CNBCreported. Share prices have risen more than 120% in the past year alone.

Apple saw a historically strong third quarter with more than $59.7 billion in revenue earned, according to a company report released in late June. “In uncertain times, this performance is a testament to the important role our products play in our customers' lives and to Apple's relentless innovation,” Apple chief executive Tim Cook said in the report.

Link to Image

Apple CEO Tim Cook speaks during an event at Apple Park in Cupertino, California (Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

The company's stock price was also bolstered by positive investor feedback towards a new four-for-one stock split announced in July which made the stock more affordable for a wider range of investors, the Associated Pressreported.

Big Tech earnings have surged this year as Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, Alphabet and Facebook stocks grew by nearly $3 trillion since March, according to The New York Times. Industry experts are predicting that other Silicon Valley companies will surpass the $2 trillion mark - which took Apple only two years after it crossed $1 trillion in August 2018.

The coronavirus pandemic has been attributed to Big Tech's financial success in recent months. Online services have become more widely used as social distancing measures and lockdowns have led to more people working from home and relying on Internet platforms, according to The Atlantic.

The power of America's largest technology companies was scrutinized at a House Judiciary Committee hearing in late July that featured CEOs Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook, Tim Cook of Apple, Jeff Bezos of Amazon and Sundar Pichai of Google. (RELATED: Trump Threatens To Sign Executive Orders To 'Bring Fairness' To Big Tech)

Democrats and Republicans alike expressed concern that tech companies were forming monopolies over industries that rely on data assets. Investigations by regulators and lawmakers into Big Tech could also spook investors and affect the companies' financial performance, according to the Associated Press.

NEW YORK, NY - JANUARY 29: Stock numbers for Apple are displayed on a screen at the Nasdaq MarketSite in Times Square, January 29, 2019 in New York City. Apple is set to report first-quarter earnings results after U.S. markets close on Tuesday. (Photo by Drew Angerer/Getty Images)

urn:contentItem:60MX-K9H1-F0PT-C1WW-00000-00Apple reaches $2trn: Has the tech rally gone too far, too fast?2020-08-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:36ZLexisNexisApple reaches $2trn: Has the tech rally gone too far, too fast?lauren.mason@incisivemedia.com(Lauren Mason)

On Wednesday (19 August), the iPhone maker's price per share reached $468 during early Wall Street trading, marking a 60% increase in the value of its shares year to date.

It was almost exactly two years ago that Apple's market cap surpassed $1trn. At time of writing, Apple accounts for 4.9% of the S&P 500 index, while the FAANG companies (Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Google) comprise about 18% of the index overall.

'Significant tailwinds' can sustain FAANG outperformance despite growing regulation risk

Chris Beauchamp, chief market analyst at IG, said Apple's push to a $2trn market cap will "delight fans of round numbers" and "confirm the primacy of big tech in this market rally", but will also provide confirmation to bearish investors that the rally has "gone too far too fast" and is "in desperate need of a pullback".

"However, there is plenty of money around, as shown by the high demand for Germany's 30-year bond auction," he pointed out. "Some of that will continue to find its way into such high momentum plays as Apple and other tech stocks."

Randeep Somel, associate fund manager (equities) at M&G Investments, said Apple's new milestone reflects consumers' increased focus and reliance on technology since the outbreak of the pandemic, but warned the future for mega-cap tech stocks is "less clear".

"Most notably, the increasing size and influence of these companies has brought with it greater scrutiny from regulators. The ability of technology companies, all of whom are sitting on vast cash reserves, to buy out new/challenger technology companies going forward will not be as easy as it has been in the past," he warned.

Legg Mason's Osmani shuns FAANGs to outperform US market

Somel said the fact tech stocks are falling under greater scrutiny of the regulators could be seen during the US congressional hearings on antitrust in July this year, where FAANG CEOs faced questions on the power of their companies in terms of pricing power, data usage and treatment of smaller competitors.

"Technology platforms are very strong, but they have buttressed their positions by acquiring smaller competitors, such as Facebook's acquisition of Instagram and Whatsapp," he continued.

"If there is greater scrutiny of large-cap tech acquiring smaller companies going forward, it will allow smaller companies to challenge and provide greater competition."

Richard Hunter, head of markets at interactive investor, said he has seen an uptick in customers who "believe more value can be squeezed from the fruit" since the beginning of the year, despite increasing regulatory concerns.

"The burning question now for investors is how high can Apple go? A deep recession could spoil Apple's bull run by knocking demand for its premium products like iPhones, iPads and MacBooks," he pointed out. "However, Apple has a few strings to its bow and its services arm, which includes Apple Music and Apple TV, is likely to continue to be a revenue driver for the business regardless of whether the overall economy is growing or not.

"In addition, the US-China trade conflict remains a threat. Further escalation in the conflict could leave Apple, who are heavily reliant on Chinese manufacturing for products such as smartphones, exposed."

Mike Kerley, portfolio manager at Janus Henderson Global Investors, agreed US-China trade tensions are also a significant factor to consider when looking at Apple, given some 17% of its revenue comes from China.

"There has been no suggestion so far that the demand for US goods is being impacted by the rising tension between the two countries, and there has been no indication in the state sponsored media so far that this might impact demand for US brands," he reasoned.

"There is precedent, however, in 2012 with Japan and 2017 with South Korea, where China took economic revenge, significantly impacting the demand for Japanese and Korean brands."

Kerley pointed out that Chinese Premier Xi Jinping would "not stand idly by indefinitely" while his "key projects and objectives are dismantled by US politicians".

"China has accounted for an ever increasing percentage of world GDP growth in the last ten years and will continue to do this in the next ten," he explained.

"As a result, higher disposable incomes will mean higher consumption of goods with the Chinese consumer accounting for a large proportion of consumption growth globally.

"American companies want and need exposure to this growth as their share prices and valuations depend on it. It is not a card Xi wants to play but it is a significant one and certainly not accounted for in stock prices at record highs."

That said, Somel pointed out that other consumer-facing FAANG stocks - notably Amazon - will benefit from the secular trend of cloud and public computing business regardless of tensions.

"The longer office workers continue to work remotely from home, the increased likelihood we have that this becomes a more permanent fixture," he said.

"This benefits cloud operators as companies scale down on-site presence (including own servers), and continue moving them to the cloud.

"That said, the upcoming rollout of 5G will be a good opportunity for handset makers to refresh their products with new technology and provide a strong update cycle. This should benefit Apple."

urn:contentItem:60MJ-6M61-JCBN-0485-00000-00Apple reboots its retail experience, now with temperature checks and long lines2020-05-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:36ZLexisNexisApple reboots its retail experience, now with temperature checks and long lines

SAN FRANCISCO - Apple's retail stores are known for crowded areas of display devices ready for experimenting and the ability to make a purchase without needing to line up at a cash register. But as the Cupertino, California-based tech giant reopens about 100 of its retail stores globally, the customer experience is bound to feel different. Apple will be enforcing strict social distancing guidelines in its stores, Apple retail and HR chief Deirdre O'Brien wrote in a public letter this weekend. The company will cap the number of people allowed in to keep at least 6 feet between everyone, will require masks and will check customers' temperatures before they enter.

Some stores will only do curbside pickup. Apple said it would also be doing "enhanced deep cleanings" on all display products, as well as tables and other parts of the store.Â  "While we know many customers are eager for their local store to reopen, our commitment is to reopen our stores when we are confident the environment is safe," Apple spokesperson Nick Leahy said in an email. Apple has been one of the tech giants most affected by the coronavirus pandemic, which hit Apple hard when it began spreading across China early this year. Apple will open at least 25 stores in seven states across the U.S. this week, adding to five it unshuttered last week. Apple stores reopening represent a slow, but accelerating, recovery for the iPhone maker. Apple was among the first of major American companies to feel the business pain of the coronavirus pandemic as many of its manufacturing plants closed across Asia early this year. Shortly after, Apple shut nearly all of its 510 retail stores across the world. The company's iPhone sales fell slightly during the first quarter of the year, an indication of how much coronavirus had shaken the company's roots. CEO Tim Cook said production levels had returned to normal, but it is unclear whether Apple is on track to launch a new version of the phone this fall, as it usually does. Big tech companies are expected to pull through the pandemic in decent economic shape overall, but Apple and Amazon have been dealing with physical effects more than others. Both companies have thousands of workers in warehouses and, in Apple's case, in retail stores. Getting those people back to work in person has meant an exercise in implementing safety measures and navigating government regulations. Apple's reopenings are a boost for the company symbolically, said Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives, and also will help financially. "The stores opening back up is a much needed shot in the arm for Cook and Cupertino," he said. It's unclear exactly how the Apple shopping experience will change with the new measures in place, which eliminate some of the custom experience of shopping at the retailer. But Apple did say people might have to wait in line if the store reaches a limited capacity, and said it will limit the number of staff each customer deals with. In Berlin, tech worker Rouzbeh Abadi said he waited in line for about 20 minutes to get into an Apple store and check out the new iPad keyboard. Apple staff members asked him why he was there, then made sure he had a mask and used hand sanitizer before he started shopping, he said. An Apple staffer stayed with him the whole time he shopped to help out, and perhaps make sure he stayed at least six feet from others, Abadi said. The experience had a different feel from what he was used to. "Before, I always went to Apple store to [browse], just because I enjoy it," he said in a message. "But now, I think I won't go there if I have no particular reason." Apple began reopening stores with similar social distancing measures in China and surrounding areas in mid-March, but waited nearly two months to start swinging open the doors of U.S. stores, as most of country remains under stay-at-home orders. By the end of the week, Apple plans to have about 30 stores open in the country, making up about 9% of its 271 U.S. locations. Stores will reopen at 25 locations in California, Washington, Florida, Colorado, Hawaii and Oklahoma this week. The company said it is following local regulations in each city and state. In California and Washington state, where the company is reopening a total of 13 stores, only curbside pickup will be allowed. "These are not decisions we rush into - and a store opening in no way means that we won't take the preventive step of closing it again should local conditions warrant," O'Brien wrote. Apple's precautions and limits on its retail stores echo what many other physical locations have already put in place - something anyone who has waited an hour to get into a grocery store this year will recognize. The future of retail for the foreseeable future will almost certainly involve masks for all, long lines and wide berths between customers. Â

Chief executive Tim Cook said production levels had returned to normal, but it is unclear whether Apple is on track to launch a new version of the phone this fall, as it usually does.

Big tech companies are expected to pull through the pandemic in decent economic shape overall, but Apple and Amazon have been dealing with physical effects more than others. Both companies have thousands of workers in warehouses and, in Apple's case, in retail stores. Getting those people back to work in person has meant an exercise in implementing safety measures and navigating government regulations.

Apple's reopenings are a boost for the company symbolically, said Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives, and also will help financially.

"The stores opening back up is a much needed shot in the arm for Cook and Cupertino," he said.

It's unclear exactly how the Apple shopping experience will change with the new measures in place, which eliminate some of the custom experience of shopping at the retailer. But Apple did say people might have to wait in line if the store reaches a limited capacity, and said it will limit the number of staff each customer deals with.

In Berlin, tech worker Rouzbeh Abadi said he waited in line for about 20 minutes to get into an Apple store and check out the new iPad magic keyboard. Apple staff asked him why he was there, then made sure he had a mask and used hand sanitizer before he started shopping, he said.

An Apple staff member stayed with him the whole time he shopped to help out - and perhaps make sure he stayed at least six feet from others, Abadi said. The experience had a different feel from what he was used to.

"Before, I always went to Apple store to [browse], just because I enjoy it," he said in a message. "But now, I think I won't go there if I have no particular reason."

Apple began reopening stores with similar social distancing measures in China and surrounding areas in mid-March, but waited nearly two months to start swinging open the doors of U.S. stores, as most of country remains under stay-at-home orders.

By the end of the week, Apple plans to have about 30 stores open in the country, making up only about 9 percent of its 271 U.S. locations. Stores will reopen at 25 locations in California, Washington, Florida, Colorado, Hawaii, Arkansas and Oklahoma this week.

The company said it is following local regulations in each city and state. In California and Washington state, where the company is reopening a total of 13 stores, only curbside pickup will be allowed.

"These are not decisions we rush into - and a store opening in no way means that we won't take the preventive step of closing it again should local conditions warrant," O'Brien wrote.

Apple's precautions and limits on its retail stores echo what many other physical locations have already put in place - something anyone who has waited an hour to get into a grocery store this year will recognize. The future of retail for the foreseeable future will almost certainly involve masks for all, long lines and wide berths between customers.

Apr 09, 2019( Broadband TV News: http://www.broadbandtvnews.com Delivered by Newstex)   https://i0.wp.com/www.broadbandtvnews.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/nab-opening-gordon.png?ssl=1The President and CEO of the NAB has criticised tech companies for failing to include broadcast-capable chips in their mobile devices.

Delivering the organisation's annual State of the Industry address at the 2019 NAB Show, Gordon Smith showed delegates an attachment that added ATSC 3.0 capability (see separate story) to a standard mobile device. The add-on allows broadcast content to be viewed on a mobile or tablet. 'While this attachment is great, what we would really love to see is a chip built into mobile devices to give consumers this technology,' Smith said. 'But to date, manufacturers, Apple being one, refuse to enable broadcast chips in their devices.' Quoting recent remarks by Democratic Senator Elizabeth Warren, Smith said the big tech companies had bulldozed competition and stifled innovation. 'I wonder if this growing tech power is one of the reasons why this consumer benefit is being held back by the manufacturers,' he continued. Smith called for the modernisation of 'outdated' broadcast regulations that would allow local broadcasters to compete on a level playing field with the larger tech and pay-TV companies to 'better ensure that broadcast journalism can flourish'. Regulation, he said, should be increased to ensure the companies could use their market power to stifle competition and the financial viability of local news.

urn:contentItem:5W0N-RKF1-F0C5-X4GM-00000-00Apple removing or restricting apps for controlling screen time2019-04-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:36ZLexisNexisApple removing or restricting apps for controlling screen timeLevi Sumagaysay

A report detailing Apple's moves raises concerns about its dominance, shines light on quality of Apple's own parental-control tools for the iPhone.

Apples removal of nearly a dozen apps that help users manage screen time raises questions about the companys dominance and its commitment to helping people stay off their iPhones amid concerns about the negative effects of smartphones, including on children, according to a new report.

The report by the New York Times on Saturday came just days after Apple CEO Tim Cook said at the Time 100 Summit last week that his company has never wanted to maximize user time because its not motivated from a business or values point of view to do so.

Thats not what developers who have had their apps removed or severely restricted say. They complained to the Times that after Apple released its own screen-time tracker last September, the company began to crack down on similar apps. An Apple spokeswoman told the newspaper that the company is concerned that the apps were accessing too much customer information.

In addition, Phil Schiller, Apple vice president for worldwide marketing, reiterated to customers that the companys crackdown is related to privacy concerns. The Times included a portion of Schillers response in its story, and MacRumors published the response in its entirety.

Schiller said the apps Apple removed were using Mobile Device Management technology, which he said is meant to be used by companies to manage devices used by their employees, to access and control iPhone users devices.

No one, except you, should have unrestricted access to manage your child's device, know their location, track their app use, control their mail accounts, web surfing, camera use, network access, and even remotely erase their devices, Schiller said in an email to a customer.

The Times also noted that Apple is facing antitrust complaints from Kidslox and Qustodio, two popular parental-control apps, in Europe. The company is facing other accusations of abusing its App Stores dominance, such as Spotify complaining to European regulators that Apple gave its Apple Music service an unfair advantage over it in the music-streaming world. In the United States, politicians and others have raised concerns about tech giants dominance. Sen. Elizabeth Warren, the Massachusetts Democrat running for president, thinks Apple should be separated from its App Store as part of her   push to rein in tech companies.

Stocks rattled a second day as U.S.-China trade tensions fester

How the Apple store lost its luster

Trumps China tariff threats lead to wild day for Bay Area tech stocks

Alexa, dont store this recording: California bill targets smart home speakers

Apple sees boost in revenue from services even as iPhone sales drop

An iPhone user quoted by the Times said Apples parental-control tools are not as good as the apps he preferred to use before they were forced to remove key features. And Tony Fadell, the co-creator of the iPhone who is no longer at Apple, weighed in on Twitter, including in his comments a dig at Apples response to the report: Apple's Screen Time still has many holes & deficiencies. Their v1.0 solution was a rush job & it's very non-intuitive to use. Apple should be building true APIs for Screen Time so the privacy concerns are taken into account instead of limiting users App Store choices.

Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood, a Boston-based advocacy group, called on Apple to work with app makers and others so parents can continue to have choices.

Parents need as many tools in the toolbox for limiting screen time as possible, said Josh Grolin, executive director for the CCFC, said Monday. If it's true that Apple is eliminating the competition, that's extremely disappointing and another indication that vertically integrated Big Tech companies have far too much power.

urn:contentItem:5FX6-BM01-JCMN-Y4T5-00000-00Apple reportedly plays dirty to kill Spotify's free tier — and I hope it gets away with it2015-05-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:36ZLexisNexisApple reportedly plays dirty to kill Spotify's free tier — and I hope it gets away with itDavid Holmes

May 04, 2015( PandoDaily: http://pandodaily.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Over at the Verge,[1] there's a report out that Apple is pushing music labels to 'force' Spotify to abandon its free, ad-supported tier. As Apple prepares to gather the ashes of Beats Music and relaunch its own streaming music service — which sources say will likely to be paid-only — this gambit would decimate Spotify's user base from 60 million total users to only 15 million paid users.

Moreover, sources told the outlet that if Universal Music Group removed its catalog from YouTube, Apple would pay the licensing fee the label conglomerate receives from that platform. (YouTube also has a streaming service in the offing). Considering Apple's ability to preload apps onto new versions of iOS — not to the mention the fact that it already has 800 million credit cards on file and so only needs to convince a tiny portion of them to sign up in order to beat Spotify — the move would be an effective knockout punch for Apple in America's streaming music fight. These tricks are dirty, unfair, and possibly illegal — especially in Europe where regulators are far tougher on big tech firms accused of antitrust violations. But you know what? Part of me sincerely hopes Apple gets away with it. Here's why. First off, as countless anti-Spotify artists have pointed out, there's nothing remotely 'fair' about labels' current arrangement with Spotify. When a listener who pays $9.99 a month for the service listens to a song, rightsholders receive ten times the royalty payment that is paid out when a listener on the free tier hears a song. The amount of revenue generated by these paid listeners is staggeringly higher[2] — both per-user and in aggregate — than the amount generated by freeloaders. In 2013, fee subscriptions like Spotify's paid tier generated $628 million for the record industry while free ad-supported listening tiers generated only $220 million (the remaining $590 million is made up of online radio royalties, primarily from Pandora). That disparity is even greater when taking into account the fact that based on generous estimates there are fewer than 30 million people worldwide who pay for Spotify, Rdio, and other streaming platforms, while there are up to 400 million monthly active users listening for free, if you include people who use YouTube to listen to music. In other words, less than ten percent of the listening public creates almost half the total revenue generated by streaming music across the board. And while Spotify's ad units have become more inventive and may become more lucrative as the company scales, it's clear that the only business model that makes sense both for artists and for the streaming services themselves — none of which have achieved longterm profitability — is one supported by paid listeners, not advertisements. There's an argument to be made, however, that most users simply won't pay for music anymore, and that if options like Spotify's free tier are taken away consumers will merely return to piracy. That may be true. Indeed, as Spotify's user base has grown the percentage of users willing to pay $9.99 a month for full mobile access and to avoid ads has held steady at only 25 percent. But that doesn't necessarily mean most users won't pay for music — it simply means most users are unwilling to pay $120 a year for music — which was true even in the cash-soaked days of CDs, when consumers paid an average of $28 a year. Meanwhile, Apple found that the average iTunes user was willing to spend $48 a year on music, or $4 a month. And so with Apple's entry into the streaming music game, we could see a repeat of the early 2000s when iTunes came in to help stop the bleeding caused by piracy — or in this case, free streaming which while somewhat more lucrative than piracy is perhaps almost as unfair — while undercutting the competition and effectively taking over as the dominant music distributor. And while labels were initially reluctant to accept Steve Jobs' terms when he proposed iTunes, the reason for these industry incumbents' misgivings was that iTunes would forever sever songs from albums — just as the Internet unbundled newspapers — thus ensuring a consumer would never again pay ten dollars or more to access just one song. Today, however, that unbundling is already the new normal in the music industry so labels have much less to lose. Of course this could be a PR nightmare for Apple — 'Tim Cook took away free music!' And there's always the possibility for unforeseen consequences when one large company controls the distribution channels within an entire industry, hence the reason for antitrust legislation. But the current system is broken. Spotify has built a huge user base by providing a complimentary service that it cannot afford to offer for free. Despite striking proprietary deals in secret with labels — deals that many artists say gives them little shot at making a fair wage — the company still isn't profitable. It doesn't work for Spotify or artists. The only constituent it does work for — other than perhaps labels who take huge percentages of the streaming revenue — is fans. But for how long? Unless users start paying — which is precisely what Apple's gambit forces — there is no foreseeable 'sustainability' in the streaming industry. And while the EU and DOJ should scrutinize Apple over these moves, the fact that by making a number of potential antitrust violations Apple would be making streaming music more fair, simply speaks to how completely unjust the status quo is. urn:contentItem:5SY1-V0W1-JBHT-D38C-00000-00Apple Reports 3Q Earnings Today; Brewing Border Battle; Trump Heads to Florida Today for Economic Rally; Trump Reportedly Agrees to Delay Funding Fight Until After Midterms; ICE Alleges Portland Mayor Violated Constitution Denying Police Support; Curtains For MoviePass; NFL Approved $500 Million In Concussion Settlements; LeBron Accuses Trump Of Using Sports To Divide People2018-07-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:36ZLexisNexisApple Reports 3Q Earnings Today; Brewing Border Battle; Trump Heads to Florida Today for Economic Rally; Trump Reportedly Agrees to Delay Funding Fight Until After Midterms; ICE Alleges Portland Mayor Violated Constitution Denying Police Support; Curtains For MoviePass; NFL Approved $500 Million In Concussion Settlements; LeBron Accuses Trump Of Using Sports To Divide PeopleLanhamFULL TEXT

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Well, all right, Dagen, three words for you, drunk online shopping.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Thank you, Cheryl, good morning everybody. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Tuesday, July 31st. Your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Earnings driving the action, three Dow components, count them three, reporting earnings today. And Apple in focus, the tech giant results are out after the closing bell. We have a preview plus a closer look at the tech wreck with key stocks entering correction territory. That's down 10 percent from the recent high.

Checking the market action this morning, we have some mixed moves. The Dow Industrial Futures are down five points but the S&P and NASDAQ moving higher. This after declines across the board yesterday with the NASDAQ, the hardest hit down more than one and one-third percent.

And despite recent weakness however, all of your market gauges, Dow, S&P, NASDAQ, even the Dow Transports, and the Russell2000 are on track for monthly gains as we wrap up the month of July.

In Europe, mixed move to report, we have a slight gain on the FT-100 in England but the French and German markets are heading lower. A reading on the euro zone economy showing slowing growth in the second quarter.

In Asia overnight markets a little changed, although we have green to report except the Hang Seng slipping half of one percent. The Bank of Japan surprising investors by keeping policy, monetary policy unchanged.

Protecting our border, President Trump doubling down on his calls for a government shutdown if funding is not approved.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: If we don't get border security after many, many years of talk within the United States, I would have no problem doing a shutdown. It's time we had proper border security.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: But one new development, a change in that timeline, the president is said to be putting a shutdown on hold until after the midterm elections. That's from a report in the Wall Street Journal this morning.

We'll hear from Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen on that, plus cyber security later this morning.

King James takes on the commander-in-chief, LeBron James getting political slamming the president by saying he's using sports to divide this country.

Plus, a homeless web developer and his plea for a job goes viral. Instead for asking for money, he asked people to take his resume and it resulted in hundreds of responses.

All that and so much more coming up this morning, FOX News Contributor Kat Timpf is here. Wall Street Journal Global Economics Editor Jon Hilsenrath. And CFRA Investment Strategist Lindsey Bell. Much to talk about with these technology stocks, the economy.

JON HILSENRATH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Absolutely. We have Apple earnings -- Apple earnings coming out later today and we have to see if this tech wreck, the correction continues.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Yes. We'll see if Apple can save the day here.

MCDOWELL: And you just teed up our A block ladies and gents, we'll hear from you as well. I know you love talking stocks.

KAT TIMPF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Absolutely. I love talking stocks. I'm like the biggest expert on this panel easily when it comes to stock.

MCDOWELL: You're an expert on a lot.

TIMPF: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That too. We'll get to that. And to our top story this hour, the earnings parade continues with Dow Components Pfizer and Proctor & Gamble reporting before the opening bell this morning.

But the earning story comes, the real one comes after the bell when Apple reports its quarterly results. Estimates are calling for earnings per share of $2.18 a share on revenue of $52.34 billion.

This is the so-called FANG stocks, Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix, and Google suffered another day of selling yesterday file -- following Facebook's massive miss last week.

Joining us now Senior Research Analyst at Neuberger Berman, Daniel Flax. Daniel, what are you looking for from Apple because this -- again, a Facebook and a Twitter problem, those are social media networks, Apple is a consumer like an electronics giant and they don't have the same -- quite the same privacy problems and user growth problems that a Facebook and Twitter do.

DANIEL FLAX, SENIOR RESEARCH ANALYST, NEUBERGER BERMAN: I think that's right Dagen. I think what we'll look for this evening is certainly the performance of the iPhone business which we know is in a seasonally weak quarter.

But also the health of the ecosystem and really understanding how services is performing. And then looking out we'll, of course, get new products likely in September. And ultimately the key for Apple is to build a differentiated user experience and leverage newer technologies like augmented reality in order to attract new users and keep their users happy and ultimately within their ecosystem.

BELL: Do you think that Apple is going to be able to provide investors what they want to hear about the new iPhones? Are they all going to be released in September or are we going to see like what we saw last year where somewhere released in September and then December quarter?

FLAX: I think it's possible that they all get announced in September. We'll have to see with the production ramp whether the availability of the devices will all be in September or some or one of them might come a little bit later.

But ultimately I think what's key for the company is that the product needs to be ready when they launch it and ultimately bring it to the market. Apple what we've seen historically would rather be a little bit late if necessary to get the product right.

And when you think about what they're doing, it's not just about this single quarter or single product, it's really what they're trying to do over the medium to longer term and create an environment that the users trust them and one have a secure experience in the Apple platform.

TIMPF: How about --

HILSENRATH: Daniel, for a long time now investors have been pushing up all these FANG stocks, the big tech stocks together in unison.

Are we at a point now where investors are starting to discriminate, whether saying, "All right. You know, Amazon is putting out good numbers, you know, we're not going to punish their stock but, you know, you're the social media guys, Twitter, Facebook just aren't living up to expectations."

Are we seeing a bifurcation finally in tech stocks and looking at -- you know, pulling apart the winners and losers?

FLAX: I think Jon what it's going to come down to is ultimately the growth. And so, we've seen in the case of say Alphabet where they're growing in their core search business, in YouTube and the cloud.

Amazon which you referenced is doing a good job both in their core e- commerce platform and newer areas like Amazon web services, their cloud business and advertising is a newer business for them too.

In the case of others like Facebook where the growth as management has telegraphed is slowing, you have that coupled with the fact that there's really a larger issue at play here in terms of how they are going to navigate the future of their user experience and as we I think all appreciate privacy data, security, that's really I think rightfully coming to the four.

And Facebook and others are trying to figure out how best to in -- to be -- allow their users to both participate in the platform and protect their data. And so the market to your point is certainly going to differentiate a lot more we think over the next several quarters and years.

MCDOWELL: But they still get lumped in altogether and the Wall Street Journal has the story at the market sector has a story today about the NYSC FANG Index and it includes every company, all of these major companies, Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google's parent, Apple, Twitter, also Tesla, (INAUDIBLE), and Alibaba.

But that's now in correction territory, it's down 10 percent from the recent high, the recent record on June 20th. Not the first time it happened this year, so that's a really important reminder Lindsey, this is the second time that group of stocks has entered correction territory this year.

BELL: Right. And I'd like to hear what you have to say but I kind of think that this move has been overdone. This is in a sector that's entirely dead, yet growth is slowing and maybe there's bigger problems within the social media aspect of technology.

But Amazon had great numbers, Microsoft, Google, Google's parent Alphabet, these are all really good reports. Even Netflix, I know it was a miss. That's what I really want to ask you about, it's around 24 percent from its most recent high this year.

The subscriber growth, the net ads, the outlook was weaker than expected, do you think that this selloff in Netflix especially is overdone as well as the overall FANG group?

FLAX: Well, with respect to the overall FANG group and Netflix, it's going to come down I think to each company's ability to drive performance and ultimately grow. I think what we appreciate in video and Netflix has certainly done a terrific job is that they need to continue to invest in content and really drive adoption certainly here but also internationally.

But there's competition, of course, and others are looking to get into the space as well. When we look at some of the broader FANG or to your point on the -- on a lot of these fast-growing companies, we really look for them and analyze them one-by-one. I think it's difficult to draw a broad -- a brush across them.

So for example you mentioned Microsoft, that's a company we continue to like and our research from talking to customers and analyzing the trends around the shift to the cloud suggest that Microsoft has a multiyear growth runway.

And so we discussed Alphabet which we continue to like but we think it's bottom of stock because you really need to be specific in what you're trying to look for in an investment and ultimately we take a longer term horizon. And so when we look at some of these names over the next one to two years, we think they're opportunities and, yes, there'll be market selloffs but if you have a longer term horizon they could be good buying opportunity.

MCDOWELL: But Jon, one thing I want to point out though, Apple and the -- again, the Journal has written a story about this last week, Apple is extremely vulnerable in terms of iPhone production to the fight that we've entered into with China because they can't readily -- their iPhones are made in China by Foxconn.

They can't readily shift production to another country for that. And we will surely hear about this on the call, but how vulnerable is Apple to this trade fight?

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, the Chinese have limited ways that they could punch back at the United States --

MCDOWELL: Right.

HILSENRATH: -- if we increased tariffs. We -- they sell a lot more to us than we sell to them, so they can't put tariffs on everything.

So, you know, one of the possible things that they could do is make life more difficult for the American companies that are operating in China. Now, it's a tough call for them because they want to make the Chinese economy receptive to foreign investment. But the -- one of the ways that they could make things difficult for the United States is by --

MCDOWELL: Increase inspections, they could send an inspector --

HILSENRATH: Exactly. How --

MCDOWELL: -- they could increase the spying that they do on their corporate executives here and really around the world. They could hold up goods at the ports whether they're going out or coming into the nation. There are whole -- are we getting any information about that at all? I mean, is information starting to trickle out?

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, I think the next big question is whether talk start up again between the U.S. and China. You know, the U.S. and the Europeans announced last week that they seem to have in agreement in the works, is the U.S. going to start talking to China again? So that's on hold right now.

MCDOWELL: Real quick Kat, I want to get your sense though because we talk about these technology stocks selling off every day despite, you know, months today all the market gauges are up. The Dow Transports are up the most of any other major market gauges.

But how much does that this affect people's, if at all, feeling about the overall economy, the wealth in the country, how -- particularly among your age group?

TIMPF: I don't think it really affects it whatsoever, I don't think people look at the small, tiny ins and outs of this. I think that people are concerned about the tariffs specifically as we just discussed.

I think that they are tax, tariffs are taxes and I don't think that people are really as excited about them as many of President Trump's supporters specifically are.

MCDOWELL: Dan, I'm going to give you final word, whatever you want to say, put an exclamation on those fours.

FLAX: So clearly issues around trade and tariffs are going to work their way through the system over the next several quarters and perhaps the next few years.

What we think is that ultimately companies that are innovating, investing, building powerful platforms that keep their users happy and enable them to grow can create tremendous value for the users, for the companies.

And as we've seen in the case of the app developers, you have the build out of digital economies. So you take a company like Apple there are a far reaching implications, positive implications for what a company like that is able to build, create, and nurture for the long-term.

MCDOWELL: Dan, good to see you. Daniel Flax, thanks for joining us this morning.

FLAX: Thanks.

MCDOWELL: And we wait for the Apple results. Coming up, California scorching wildfire is so large and burning so hot that it's now creating its own weather system. Plus, how the military is waging the war on that blaze.

CBS under fire, CEO Les Moonves will stay put for now amid sexual harassment allegations. The board of directors taking a major action to get some answers. More on that next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The Dow is searching for some direction this morning but we still have green across the board to wrap up the month July, 12-point gain on the Futures.

But to emphasize this, every single major market gauge is up for the month of July despite the selloff in technology, even the NASDAQ is in the green for the month. The biggest winner are the Dow Transports. Dow Transports are up nearly six percent so far in July. And if you're a big believer in old theories about the market, that is a really healthy sign for the economy.

Moving on to the U.S. military joining the fight against the deadly Carr Fire in California, Cheryl Casone has more details. Cheryl.

CASONE: That's right Dagen, the deadly wildfire in Northern California has now burned over 100,000 acres. Some 12,000 firefighters are battling this fire right now. This is the ninth most destructive wildfire in the state's history.

Fires are powerful, it is creating its own weather system with strong winds making it difficult for fire officials to predict which way it's going to spread next. Carr Fire is about 23 percent contained right now.

At about 800 California National Guard Troops are also fighting the wildfire, the military has also deployed its Chinook and Black Hawk helicopters to assist rescue crews and fire crews with this devastating tragedy out in California.

Well, the CBS board of directors has decided to use outside council to conduct an investigation into CEO Les Moonves after he was accused of sexual misconduct. The investigation follows a report (INAUDIBLE) which six women there accused Moonves of sexual misconduct.

CBS reports its second quarter earnings on Thursday. Shares of CBS are down about eight percent this year, the board, of course, speaking yesterday.

Well, General Electric is selling off its digital assets. They are shedding a key software initiative of former CEO Immelt. G.E. Digital has continued to lose money despite billions of dollars in investment. Company has now hired an investment bank to run an auction for the operation. Shares of G.E. are down 25 percent so far this year.

And then finally there is this, pretty neat story of perseverance. A homeless man received more than 200 job offers after handing out resumes while he was standing next to a highway. This happened in Silicon Valley of all places.

Twenty-six-year-old David Casares dressed up in a suit, held a sign that read, "Homeless, hungry for success. Take a resume." His luck changed after his job pitch went viral on the internet. Casares who by the way has a degree, college degree planned a launch to tech startup but he ran out of money.

Some of the job offers reportedly are coming from Netflix, Google, even Pandora, Dagen. So the moral of the story, Silicon Valley does have a heart. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Absolutely. Kat Timpf, I know you love this story.

TIMPF: Oh, I love it. It's my absolute favorite, yes. This is so, so, so nice.

MCDOWELL: Because it's ingenuity and --

TIMPF: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- it's, you know, pull yourself up by your boot straps and, again, it's --

TIMPF: And anyone --

MCDOWELL: -- people reaching out to those (INAUDIBLE)

TIMPF: Yes. Anyone can just, you know, ask for money and that's really sad to see something like that. But this guy, someone who believes in himself. He says, "I have something to offer. I can take a job, I can do this for you." And I think that's absolutely wonderful.

HILSENRATH: Can I give you the geek response to this? I --

MCDOWELL: I fully expect that Jon Hilsenrath from you.

HILSENRATH: See this has read another example of how tight our labor market is. We've got a four percent unemployment rate and companies everywhere are just -- they're literally searching the streets for people, for labor.

TIMPF: Yes. There's more jobs right now than there are people to fill them. So I think that this is a great idea.

HILSENRATH: And so a man on a street can get a job. But, you know, we see this with dis -- people with disabilities getting jobs, ex-convicts getting jobs, minority unemployment rates are lower than they've ever been before. This is a great example of that.

MCDOWELL: Yes. It really is an incredible economy. That it is opening itself to one and all.

BELL: Well -- and I think this guy actually had the skill set that, you know, Google and Alphabet and those company -- the tech companies wanted that were reaching out to him.

MCDOWELL: But some of the people at those companies when it comes to hiring, they can be pretty ha-ha-ha and haughty about where you went to college and they want Ivys but you know what, there's some incredible people who didn't go to Ivy League schools. And that --

BELL: I agree.

MCDOWELL: And that shines a light on maybe you need to wipe away that snootiness at some of these tech companies.

BELL: Absolutely.

MCDOWELL: I know that for a fact. Coming up, President Trump doubling down for his cause for a government shutdown if border wall funding is not approved. But why is changing his timelines for that threat, that's ahead.

And never leave anything or anyone in the backseat again. The details on Nissan's innovative alarm system becoming a standard feature.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We are working closely with our European partners including Italy to ensure fair and reciprocal trade. Now is also the perfect time to expand commerce between the United States and Italy.

America's booming economy setting records in so many categories creates enormous opportunities for investment.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: That was President Trump talking trade after meeting with Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte yesterday and he heads to Florida later today, expected to tout strong economic growth at a workforce event and a -- and a Make America Great Again Rally.

Kat, what would you like to hear from the president tonight? Because our - - the trade issue and how strong the economy are, are they one -- are they tied together or are they opposite ends of the spectrum in terms of saying what his supporters want to hear?

TIMPF: I think that they're definitely a little bit separate. The economy is doing very well right now. But when you talk about trade and tariffs particularly, there are some bit of a risk there when it comes to the economy.

And I just think that it's very interesting that this is a republican president, this is a president who says he's conservative but the conservative point of view has always been more of a free trade point of view and now President Trump with his America first type of view, that's really more of a democratic view or at least it has been in the past.

MCDOWELL: Well Jon, that's the interesting this is that he really -- this is the strange middle ground where people act like that the democrats and republicans or people who are liberal and conservative don't meet.

But when it turn -- when it comes to getting tough on people who have been cheating us and I named China, they've been stealing intellectual property from us, forcing the surrender of our own technology. When he's able to talk about that, it does bring different groups of people together. And certainly rallies of interesting voter-base if you will.

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, what the president did in the 2016 election was take over blue collar America basically. You know, he taps in to people who feel disaffected by trade in manufacturing towns in particular.

And when people see him pushing back on China in those places, it rally support for him. The question is, what does it do for the rest of the country, you know, when you talk about putting -- pushing tariffs through on automobiles, you could be talking about cars that caused you $24,000 instead of $20,000.

MCDOWELL: But he did -- but he deescalated that fight last week meeting with Jean-Claude Juncker from the European Commission. That seems to at least be on hold. That was arguably the biggest concern for the stock market.
