urn:contentItem:5VMD-VRY1-DY0W-4089-00000-00Apple Reports 3Q Earnings Today; Brewing Border Battle; Trump Heads to Florida Today for Economic Rally; Trump Reportedly Agrees to Delay Funding Fight Until After Midterms; ICE Alleges Portland Mayor Violated Constitution Denying Police Support; Curtains For MoviePass; NFL Approved $500 Million In Concussion Settlements; LeBron Accuses Trump Of Using Sports To Divide People2018-07-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:36ZLexisNexisApple Reports 3Q Earnings Today; Brewing Border Battle; Trump Heads to Florida Today for Economic Rally; Trump Reportedly Agrees to Delay Funding Fight Until After Midterms; ICE Alleges Portland Mayor Violated Constitution Denying Police Support; Curtains For MoviePass; NFL Approved $500 Million In Concussion Settlements; LeBron Accuses Trump Of Using Sports To Divide PeopleLanhamFULL TEXT

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Well, all right, Dagen, three words for you, drunk online shopping.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Thank you, Cheryl, good morning everybody. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Tuesday, July 31st. Your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Earnings driving the action, three Dow components, count them three, reporting earnings today. And Apple in focus, the tech giant results are out after the closing bell. We have a preview plus a closer look at the tech wreck with key stocks entering correction territory. That's down 10 percent from the recent high.

Checking the market action this morning, we have some mixed moves. The Dow Industrial Futures are down five points but the S&P and NASDAQ moving higher. This after declines across the board yesterday with the NASDAQ, the hardest hit down more than one and one-third percent.

And despite recent weakness however, all of your market gauges, Dow, S&P, NASDAQ, even the Dow Transports, and the Russell2000 are on track for monthly gains as we wrap up the month of July.

In Europe, mixed move to report, we have a slight gain on the FT-100 in England but the French and German markets are heading lower. A reading on the euro zone economy showing slowing growth in the second quarter.

In Asia overnight markets a little changed, although we have green to report except the Hang Seng slipping half of one percent. The Bank of Japan surprising investors by keeping policy, monetary policy unchanged.

Protecting our border, President Trump doubling down on his calls for a government shutdown if funding is not approved.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: If we don't get border security after many, many years of talk within the United States, I would have no problem doing a shutdown. It's time we had proper border security.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: But one new development, a change in that timeline, the president is said to be putting a shutdown on hold until after the midterm elections. That's from a report in the Wall Street Journal this morning.

We'll hear from Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen on that, plus cyber security later this morning.

King James takes on the commander-in-chief, LeBron James getting political slamming the president by saying he's using sports to divide this country.

Plus, a homeless web developer and his plea for a job goes viral. Instead for asking for money, he asked people to take his resume and it resulted in hundreds of responses.

All that and so much more coming up this morning, FOX News Contributor Kat Timpf is here. Wall Street Journal Global Economics Editor Jon Hilsenrath. And CFRA Investment Strategist Lindsey Bell. Much to talk about with these technology stocks, the economy.

JON HILSENRATH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Absolutely. We have Apple earnings -- Apple earnings coming out later today and we have to see if this tech wreck, the correction continues.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Yes. We'll see if Apple can save the day here.

MCDOWELL: And you just teed up our A block ladies and gents, we'll hear from you as well. I know you love talking stocks.

KAT TIMPF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Absolutely. I love talking stocks. I'm like the biggest expert on this panel easily when it comes to stock.

MCDOWELL: You're an expert on a lot.

TIMPF: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That too. We'll get to that. And to our top story this hour, the earnings parade continues with Dow Components Pfizer and Proctor & Gamble reporting before the opening bell this morning.

But the earning story comes, the real one comes after the bell when Apple reports its quarterly results. Estimates are calling for earnings per share of $2.18 a share on revenue of $52.34 billion.

This is the so-called FANG stocks, Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix, and Google suffered another day of selling yesterday file -- following Facebook's massive miss last week.

Joining us now Senior Research Analyst at Neuberger Berman, Daniel Flax. Daniel, what are you looking for from Apple because this -- again, a Facebook and a Twitter problem, those are social media networks, Apple is a consumer like an electronics giant and they don't have the same -- quite the same privacy problems and user growth problems that a Facebook and Twitter do.

DANIEL FLAX, SENIOR RESEARCH ANALYST, NEUBERGER BERMAN: I think that's right Dagen. I think what we'll look for this evening is certainly the performance of the iPhone business which we know is in a seasonally weak quarter.

But also the health of the ecosystem and really understanding how services is performing. And then looking out we'll, of course, get new products likely in September. And ultimately the key for Apple is to build a differentiated user experience and leverage newer technologies like augmented reality in order to attract new users and keep their users happy and ultimately within their ecosystem.

BELL: Do you think that Apple is going to be able to provide investors what they want to hear about the new iPhones? Are they all going to be released in September or are we going to see like what we saw last year where somewhere released in September and then December quarter?

FLAX: I think it's possible that they all get announced in September. We'll have to see with the production ramp whether the availability of the devices will all be in September or some or one of them might come a little bit later.

But ultimately I think what's key for the company is that the product needs to be ready when they launch it and ultimately bring it to the market. Apple what we've seen historically would rather be a little bit late if necessary to get the product right.

And when you think about what they're doing, it's not just about this single quarter or single product, it's really what they're trying to do over the medium to longer term and create an environment that the users trust them and one have a secure experience in the Apple platform.

TIMPF: How about --

HILSENRATH: Daniel, for a long time now investors have been pushing up all these FANG stocks, the big tech stocks together in unison.

Are we at a point now where investors are starting to discriminate, whether saying, "All right. You know, Amazon is putting out good numbers, you know, we're not going to punish their stock but, you know, you're the social media guys, Twitter, Facebook just aren't living up to expectations."

Are we seeing a bifurcation finally in tech stocks and looking at -- you know, pulling apart the winners and losers?

FLAX: I think Jon what it's going to come down to is ultimately the growth. And so, we've seen in the case of say Alphabet where they're growing in their core search business, in YouTube and the cloud.

Amazon which you referenced is doing a good job both in their core e- commerce platform and newer areas like Amazon web services, their cloud business and advertising is a newer business for them too.

In the case of others like Facebook where the growth as management has telegraphed is slowing, you have that coupled with the fact that there's really a larger issue at play here in terms of how they are going to navigate the future of their user experience and as we I think all appreciate privacy data, security, that's really I think rightfully coming to the four.

And Facebook and others are trying to figure out how best to in -- to be -- allow their users to both participate in the platform and protect their data. And so the market to your point is certainly going to differentiate a lot more we think over the next several quarters and years.

MCDOWELL: But they still get lumped in altogether and the Wall Street Journal has the story at the market sector has a story today about the NYSC FANG Index and it includes every company, all of these major companies, Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google's parent, Apple, Twitter, also Tesla, (INAUDIBLE), and Alibaba.

But that's now in correction territory, it's down 10 percent from the recent high, the recent record on June 20th. Not the first time it happened this year, so that's a really important reminder Lindsey, this is the second time that group of stocks has entered correction territory this year.

BELL: Right. And I'd like to hear what you have to say but I kind of think that this move has been overdone. This is in a sector that's entirely dead, yet growth is slowing and maybe there's bigger problems within the social media aspect of technology.

But Amazon had great numbers, Microsoft, Google, Google's parent Alphabet, these are all really good reports. Even Netflix, I know it was a miss. That's what I really want to ask you about, it's around 24 percent from its most recent high this year.

The subscriber growth, the net ads, the outlook was weaker than expected, do you think that this selloff in Netflix especially is overdone as well as the overall FANG group?

FLAX: Well, with respect to the overall FANG group and Netflix, it's going to come down I think to each company's ability to drive performance and ultimately grow. I think what we appreciate in video and Netflix has certainly done a terrific job is that they need to continue to invest in content and really drive adoption certainly here but also internationally.

But there's competition, of course, and others are looking to get into the space as well. When we look at some of the broader FANG or to your point on the -- on a lot of these fast-growing companies, we really look for them and analyze them one-by-one. I think it's difficult to draw a broad -- a brush across them.

So for example you mentioned Microsoft, that's a company we continue to like and our research from talking to customers and analyzing the trends around the shift to the cloud suggest that Microsoft has a multiyear growth runway.

And so we discussed Alphabet which we continue to like but we think it's bottom of stock because you really need to be specific in what you're trying to look for in an investment and ultimately we take a longer term horizon. And so when we look at some of these names over the next one to two years, we think they're opportunities and, yes, there'll be market selloffs but if you have a longer term horizon they could be good buying opportunity.

MCDOWELL: But Jon, one thing I want to point out though, Apple and the -- again, the Journal has written a story about this last week, Apple is extremely vulnerable in terms of iPhone production to the fight that we've entered into with China because they can't readily -- their iPhones are made in China by Foxconn.

They can't readily shift production to another country for that. And we will surely hear about this on the call, but how vulnerable is Apple to this trade fight?

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, the Chinese have limited ways that they could punch back at the United States --

MCDOWELL: Right.

HILSENRATH: -- if we increased tariffs. We -- they sell a lot more to us than we sell to them, so they can't put tariffs on everything.

So, you know, one of the possible things that they could do is make life more difficult for the American companies that are operating in China. Now, it's a tough call for them because they want to make the Chinese economy receptive to foreign investment. But the -- one of the ways that they could make things difficult for the United States is by --

MCDOWELL: Increase inspections, they could send an inspector --

HILSENRATH: Exactly. How --

MCDOWELL: -- they could increase the spying that they do on their corporate executives here and really around the world. They could hold up goods at the ports whether they're going out or coming into the nation. There are whole -- are we getting any information about that at all? I mean, is information starting to trickle out?

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, I think the next big question is whether talk start up again between the U.S. and China. You know, the U.S. and the Europeans announced last week that they seem to have in agreement in the works, is the U.S. going to start talking to China again? So that's on hold right now.

MCDOWELL: Real quick Kat, I want to get your sense though because we talk about these technology stocks selling off every day despite, you know, months today all the market gauges are up. The Dow Transports are up the most of any other major market gauges.

But how much does that this affect people's, if at all, feeling about the overall economy, the wealth in the country, how -- particularly among your age group?

TIMPF: I don't think it really affects it whatsoever, I don't think people look at the small, tiny ins and outs of this. I think that people are concerned about the tariffs specifically as we just discussed.

I think that they are tax, tariffs are taxes and I don't think that people are really as excited about them as many of President Trump's supporters specifically are.

MCDOWELL: Dan, I'm going to give you final word, whatever you want to say, put an exclamation on those fours.

FLAX: So clearly issues around trade and tariffs are going to work their way through the system over the next several quarters and perhaps the next few years.

What we think is that ultimately companies that are innovating, investing, building powerful platforms that keep their users happy and enable them to grow can create tremendous value for the users, for the companies.

And as we've seen in the case of the app developers, you have the build out of digital economies. So you take a company like Apple there are a far reaching implications, positive implications for what a company like that is able to build, create, and nurture for the long-term.

MCDOWELL: Dan, good to see you. Daniel Flax, thanks for joining us this morning.

FLAX: Thanks.

MCDOWELL: And we wait for the Apple results. Coming up, California scorching wildfire is so large and burning so hot that it's now creating its own weather system. Plus, how the military is waging the war on that blaze.

CBS under fire, CEO Les Moonves will stay put for now amid sexual harassment allegations. The board of directors taking a major action to get some answers. More on that next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The Dow is searching for some direction this morning but we still have green across the board to wrap up the month July, 12-point gain on the Futures.

But to emphasize this, every single major market gauge is up for the month of July despite the selloff in technology, even the NASDAQ is in the green for the month. The biggest winner are the Dow Transports. Dow Transports are up nearly six percent so far in July. And if you're a big believer in old theories about the market, that is a really healthy sign for the economy.

Moving on to the U.S. military joining the fight against the deadly Carr Fire in California, Cheryl Casone has more details. Cheryl.

CASONE: That's right Dagen, the deadly wildfire in Northern California has now burned over 100,000 acres. Some 12,000 firefighters are battling this fire right now. This is the ninth most destructive wildfire in the state's history.

Fires are powerful, it is creating its own weather system with strong winds making it difficult for fire officials to predict which way it's going to spread next. Carr Fire is about 23 percent contained right now.

At about 800 California National Guard Troops are also fighting the wildfire, the military has also deployed its Chinook and Black Hawk helicopters to assist rescue crews and fire crews with this devastating tragedy out in California.

Well, the CBS board of directors has decided to use outside council to conduct an investigation into CEO Les Moonves after he was accused of sexual misconduct. The investigation follows a report (INAUDIBLE) which six women there accused Moonves of sexual misconduct.

CBS reports its second quarter earnings on Thursday. Shares of CBS are down about eight percent this year, the board, of course, speaking yesterday.

Well, General Electric is selling off its digital assets. They are shedding a key software initiative of former CEO Immelt. G.E. Digital has continued to lose money despite billions of dollars in investment. Company has now hired an investment bank to run an auction for the operation. Shares of G.E. are down 25 percent so far this year.

And then finally there is this, pretty neat story of perseverance. A homeless man received more than 200 job offers after handing out resumes while he was standing next to a highway. This happened in Silicon Valley of all places.

Twenty-six-year-old David Casares dressed up in a suit, held a sign that read, "Homeless, hungry for success. Take a resume." His luck changed after his job pitch went viral on the internet. Casares who by the way has a degree, college degree planned a launch to tech startup but he ran out of money.

Some of the job offers reportedly are coming from Netflix, Google, even Pandora, Dagen. So the moral of the story, Silicon Valley does have a heart. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Absolutely. Kat Timpf, I know you love this story.

TIMPF: Oh, I love it. It's my absolute favorite, yes. This is so, so, so nice.

MCDOWELL: Because it's ingenuity and --

TIMPF: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- it's, you know, pull yourself up by your boot straps and, again, it's --

TIMPF: And anyone --

MCDOWELL: -- people reaching out to those (INAUDIBLE)

TIMPF: Yes. Anyone can just, you know, ask for money and that's really sad to see something like that. But this guy, someone who believes in himself. He says, "I have something to offer. I can take a job, I can do this for you." And I think that's absolutely wonderful.

HILSENRATH: Can I give you the geek response to this? I --

MCDOWELL: I fully expect that Jon Hilsenrath from you.

HILSENRATH: See this has read another example of how tight our labor market is. We've got a four percent unemployment rate and companies everywhere are just -- they're literally searching the streets for people, for labor.

TIMPF: Yes. There's more jobs right now than there are people to fill them. So I think that this is a great idea.

HILSENRATH: And so a man on a street can get a job. But, you know, we see this with dis -- people with disabilities getting jobs, ex-convicts getting jobs, minority unemployment rates are lower than they've ever been before. This is a great example of that.

MCDOWELL: Yes. It really is an incredible economy. That it is opening itself to one and all.

BELL: Well -- and I think this guy actually had the skill set that, you know, Google and Alphabet and those company -- the tech companies wanted that were reaching out to him.

MCDOWELL: But some of the people at those companies when it comes to hiring, they can be pretty ha-ha-ha and haughty about where you went to college and they want Ivys but you know what, there's some incredible people who didn't go to Ivy League schools. And that --

BELL: I agree.

MCDOWELL: And that shines a light on maybe you need to wipe away that snootiness at some of these tech companies.

BELL: Absolutely.

MCDOWELL: I know that for a fact. Coming up, President Trump doubling down for his cause for a government shutdown if border wall funding is not approved. But why is changing his timelines for that threat, that's ahead.

And never leave anything or anyone in the backseat again. The details on Nissan's innovative alarm system becoming a standard feature.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We are working closely with our European partners including Italy to ensure fair and reciprocal trade. Now is also the perfect time to expand commerce between the United States and Italy.

America's booming economy setting records in so many categories creates enormous opportunities for investment.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: That was President Trump talking trade after meeting with Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte yesterday and he heads to Florida later today, expected to tout strong economic growth at a workforce event and a -- and a Make America Great Again Rally.

Kat, what would you like to hear from the president tonight? Because our - - the trade issue and how strong the economy are, are they one -- are they tied together or are they opposite ends of the spectrum in terms of saying what his supporters want to hear?

TIMPF: I think that they're definitely a little bit separate. The economy is doing very well right now. But when you talk about trade and tariffs particularly, there are some bit of a risk there when it comes to the economy.

And I just think that it's very interesting that this is a republican president, this is a president who says he's conservative but the conservative point of view has always been more of a free trade point of view and now President Trump with his America first type of view, that's really more of a democratic view or at least it has been in the past.

MCDOWELL: Well Jon, that's the interesting this is that he really -- this is the strange middle ground where people act like that the democrats and republicans or people who are liberal and conservative don't meet.

But when it turn -- when it comes to getting tough on people who have been cheating us and I named China, they've been stealing intellectual property from us, forcing the surrender of our own technology. When he's able to talk about that, it does bring different groups of people together. And certainly rallies of interesting voter-base if you will.

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, what the president did in the 2016 election was take over blue collar America basically. You know, he taps in to people who feel disaffected by trade in manufacturing towns in particular.

And when people see him pushing back on China in those places, it rally support for him. The question is, what does it do for the rest of the country, you know, when you talk about putting -- pushing tariffs through on automobiles, you could be talking about cars that caused you $24,000 instead of $20,000.

MCDOWELL: But he did -- but he deescalated that fight last week meeting with Jean-Claude Juncker from the European Commission. That seems to at least be on hold. That was arguably the biggest concern for the stock market.

HILSENRATH: Well what a lot of people have been arguing to him is that he needs to focus on China and stop going after allies like Canada and Europe.

And I -- we just -- it's hard to know what his strategy is but what we might have seen is that pivot taking place next week. And so what I'm waiting to see is what his next step going to be on the Chinese. There hasn't been any talks for several weeks now, are they going to get back to talking or is he going to ratchet things up? And we just don't know where he stands there.

MCDOWELL: Let's talk about China. China as Jon pointed out, we have a lot more leverage in terms of the amount, we buy more than half a trillion worth of goods from China every year. They buy about $130 billion from the United States.

China is already feeling the effects of tariffs, economic growth is beginning to slow due to lower demand for domestic goods. Here is Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on solidifying the U.S.'s economic position overseas.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE POMPEO, U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE: The Trump Administration is committed to expanding our economic engagement in the Indo-Pacific region. We seek to capitalize an opportunities and, of course, with the principles of freedom and openness.

Every nation of business can have confidence that the United States will continue to create the conditions from mutual prosperity and a free and open Indo-Pacific. President Trump will strike when the iron is hot because there are clear economic benefits at hand for the American people.

We seek to work with anyone to promote a free and open Indo-Pacific so long as that cooperation adheres to the highest standards that our citizens demand.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Lindsey, your thoughts on that?

BELL: You see, I think this is where the Trump Administration is showing that they really do want open and free trade across the globe and especially within the Asian market. And with China in particular, these tariffs are the Trump Administration's way of getting China to the table to maybe negotiate better trade deal and address the theft of intellectual property and technology.

The question is though, is it going to -- when are they going to come to the table for us to begin negotiation?

HILSENRATH: But I'm going to take issue with that because the very first thing that President Trump did after his inauguration was pull the U.S. out of the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

So it's kind of hard to listen to the Secretary of State talking about, you know, the U.S. being open to trade with the Pacific when it pulled out of the TPP which was supposed to tighten our trade alliances with the non- Chinese -- with non-Chinese countries in the Pacific.

MCDOWELL: Right or wrong though he's been exceedingly focused on doing what he said on the campaign trail. He's been focused on if I said it, I'm going to do it and that's why you see this fixation on the border wall --

HILSENRATH: But that just doesn't help with what Pompeo said. You know, he is following through on what he said he was going to do on the campaign trail but that means actually pushing some of our allies in the wrong direction.

TIMPF: He's been all over the place on certain issues, foreign policies, things like that. But when it comes to this America First idea, he's been very consistent the entire time.

MCDOWELL: He has. And I want to get your read, we're going to talk about it later, I'm going to tease this Morgan Stanley is warning clients to prepare for the biggest stock market selloff in months, so hold that. You're going to have to wait. I don't know when I'll get to ask them about it but I will be asking you about that very thing.

Meantime, President Trump he tweets this, "The globalist Koch Brothers who have become a total joke in real republican circles are against strong borders and powerful trade. I never sought their support because I don't need their money or bad ideas. They love my tax and regulation cuts, judicial picks and more."

"I made them richer, their network is highly overrated. I have beaten them at every turn, they want to protect their companies outside the U.S. from being taxed. I'm for America First and the American worker. A puppet for no one. Two nice guys with bad ideas. Make America great again."

TIMPF: Typical Trump tweet.

MCDOWELL: Yes, it is. And he basically covered everything we were just talking about.

Coming up, the mayor or Portland, Oregon under fire, accused of turning his back on ICE workers in support of protesters who want to abolish the agency.

And LeBron James has a new opponent, President Trump. The NBA star says the President of the United States is a divider when it comes to the NFL protests. The new comments, ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Good morning, I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Tuesday, July 31st, your top stories at 6:30 a.m. Eastern.

Earnings in focus, Dow components Procter & Gamble and Pfizer both reporting this morning, and one biggie, Apple, reports this afternoon after the closing bell, this follows last week's disappointing news from the likes of Facebook and Twitter that set off some big losses for those companies and other big name technology stocks.

Let's take a look at how Futures are holding up this morning, a 21-point gain on the Dow Futures. We have green across the board. And as we move into -- the markets finished in the red, yesterday. The NASDAQ lost more than one percent, but we are wrapping up the month of July today.

And every single major market gauge is higher, even the Russell 2000 and the transports, transports being the biggest winner, so far this month.

European markets are mixed this morning. Right now, it's green across the board. We have gains at the moment in England, France and Germany. And in Asia overnight, it was the same story, the only loser there, Japan, Shanghai and the KOSPI in South Korea, all heading higher, the only loser, the Hang Seng in Hong Kong.

Well, it's building a wall, the wall, President Trump speaking out again on, yesterday, on securing America's borders.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We have immigration laws, we have border security, we have all sorts of things going on that are -- it's disgraceful. We are doing a phenomenal job, we're setting records, but we have laws that don't work. So, we're working around those laws and it's unfortunate.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The President threatening government shutdown over border security votes, but one administration official says that the fight will happen after the midterm elections now. We'll hear from Homeland Security Secretary, Kirstjen Nielsen, on that, plus, cybersecurity, later this morning.

LeBron James, squaring off against President Trump, the basketball star saying that the President is using sports to divide the nation, his inflammatory comments, LeBron James' inflammatory comments, coming up.

Plus, it's curtains for movie pass, the movie tickets subscription service says it is blocking viewers from buying tickets for major upcoming releases and a controversial move to try and save the company.

Now, to our top story this half hour, President Trump, doubling down on his threat of a government shutdown if Congress does not provide funding for border security.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I would certainly be willing to close it down to get it done. As you know, we are already approving things in various bills including we're going to be taking care of the military, we always put the military and law enforcement very high. But I would be certainly willing to consider a shutdown if we don't get proper border security.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: However, one administration official says that the President has agreed to delay the fight over border security until after the midterm elections in early November. This is according to a story that's in the Wall Street Journal today. Here now, Bre Payton, Staff Writer for the Federalist. Bre, how important is the border security in the wall for Republican voters this fall and would a shutdown actually rally the base?

BRE PAYTON, STAFF WRITER, THE FEDERALIST: Yes, I think that this speaks to a larger issue within Congress and just how dysfunctional it is. I mean, this is an entity that hasn't passed a real budget in something like 20 years.

And the only time you're able to get them to pass just a continuing resolution is when there is a shutdown looming. So, I think, rhetorically, it makes sense for Donald Trump to threaten this because this is the only time we ever see Congress actually taking things seriously and actually doing things.

I also think it's not surprising that there is an administration official out there who is reportedly saying that Trump will -- is expected to, kind of, soften this eventually. This is what we have seen, kind of, time and time again. I mean, you know, voters were promised a giant massive wall that Mexico was going to pay for. And it was going to be just this entire wall of concrete.

And, you know, now, it's like, OK, we are going to get a wall in certain sections along the border and, right. So I think that there is the tough line that comes out and then there is a bit of a softening and realization and a willingness to be a little bit more realistic, given geographic or just other political constraints that he's facing.

MCDOWELL: Kat Timpf.

TIMPF: Yes. Bre, this is Kat, hi, so what is the point then, of -- he's already said he's going to do it. What do you think is the point of waiting until after the midterm elections?

PAYTON: Yes, I mean, politically, I can understand why you would just want to delay that. I think that that would spur Republican voters to come out and say, OK, we've got to vote a lot of Republicans in there in order to make sure that we can get the wall that we have been wanting throughout this whole time.

And I think it's also a motivator for Democrats to say, you know, let's not -- let's make sure that we get our people in, in order to make sure that this wall, the funding for this wall doesn't happen, that it doesn't go through.

So, I guess, I can see how this is a motivator for both sides of the issue, and I think it'll be interesting to see how this plays out in November.

MCDOWELL: Jon Hilsenrath, though, I mentioned earlier, Trump has delivered on essentially every promise that he made on the campaign trail, except for the wall funding. There was only $1.6 billion in that gigantic omnibus spending bill which the President did sign, a $1.6 billion for, essentially, fencing replacement -- fencing for the wall. And there were no restrictions on these sanctuary cities.

Congress carries the power of the purse, they didn't put anything in there to deprive those cities of funding and the President, after signing that omnibus spending bill, he was clearly upset by that.

HILSENRATH: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Do you think it comes to a government shutdown even though the Journal is reporting that there's some behind the scenes agreement to avoid that until after November?

HILSENRATH: I think what's going on here is the President has lost his patience. And this reminds me a little bit of what happened in the trade fight, you know. In his first year in office, a lot of his top advisers, including Gary Cohn, tried to put off confrontations over trade.

And then finally lost his patience, and he said, no, we are going to -- we're going to do -- we're going to move forward with tariffs, and he did. And that's been the story of 2018. I think he lost his patience on this question of border security and the border wall.

But now, instead of people like Gary Cohn, you have people like Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell say, all right, just wait until after the election because this is a political loser for the Republican Party, when they are trying to hold to the House.

So, I think, he is going to carry forward with the threats, but they're just trying to hold them off to make sure that they don't lose the House in the process.

MCDOWELL: Well, speaking of Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell, although they - - some Trump supporters see them as the enemy, maybe not as much, Bre, as the Democrats. Nevertheless, it is the House, largely, and Mitch McConnell in the Senate that pushed through President Trump's biggest legislative win, and that's those tax cuts.

And that's one of the reasons that the economy is growing north of four percent right now. That's one of the reasons that unemployment is so incredibly low, that we got more job openings, than people who are unemployed at this point. So, again, if you want to side -- you want to run on the economy above anything and everything else.

PAYTON: Yes, absolutely. And I think the economy, even though it was politically difficult for them to get it done at the time, I think that's a bigger priority and a bigger win. I'm putting that in quotes than the border wall would be necessarily for them.

So, I think -- I guess, it, kind of, makes sense that that was able to get done before this border wall funding was able to get done. And I think this also speaks to the larger dysfunction within the Republican Party, which is that, you know, they haven't been recruiting individuals that are going to vote a certain way across the country.

They haven't been, you know, putting together a strong coalition that's going to vote as a block. And they don't use carrots and sticks. They don't throw people off of committees if they don't vote the way that they want them to, and I think that that speaks to a larger problem within leadership, that they aren't willing to use the tools at their disposal in order to get things done.

MCDOWELL: Moving on to this story, Bre, ICE, is alleging that mayor of Portland, violated the constitution by supporting Abolish ICE protesters, ordering the police to stand down and failing to protect ICE employees. Do cities like Portland hurt the Democratic Party ahead of the midterms in terms of messaging?

PAYTON: Oh, I think, absolutely. I mean, listen, if you're upset about the way that ICE is handling itself, if you're upset about the policies, there's a way and the means in order to protest, and speak out against it and raise media attention.

I mean, individuals were upset that ICE was separating individuals coming over illegally, separating families from their parents or separating individuals coming over together. And ICE has changed that policy.

So there is a way to affect change, and it's not by confronting disabled veterans while he's reportedly going to pick up his daughter from summer camp. That's not the way to do that. And, I think, Portland mayor reportedly telling police to stand down and not interfere with these protestors and protect ICE federal employees.

I think that that's totally nuts and reveals that many within the Democratic Party, they really just don't like the fact that we have a border. They don't like the fact that there are laws. I think it's demonstrated that the Democratic Party, many factions of it, however, I should say, have jumped the shark on this issue.

MCDOWELL: Yes. And I would just encourage all of these elected officials to go online and actually read what ICE does in terms of disrupting and breaking up child trafficking and human trafficking. As if that that's not a valuable necessary task that ICE takes on each and every day, and many women putting their lives at risk for that.

Bre, good to see you, thank you so much.

PAYTON: Good to see you too, thank you.

MCDOWELL: Bre Payton. Stay tuned as both Florida Congressman Ron DeSantis, he wants to be governor down in Florida, and President Trump is heading in that direction down to Tampa for a rally, this evening, and also, Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen, are coming up later in the show.

But shortly, LeBron James takes on the commander in chief, why the NBA star is saying the President is using sports to divide this country. Plus -- and movie pass, not getting a pass from fans after the company pulls major movies like Mission Impossible Fallout, from its program, the internet backlash, instant and brutal.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Good news for Credit Suisse and its shareholders. Cheryl Casone has the details, Cheryl.

CASONE: Dagen, that is right. Credit Suisse now on track to report its first annual profit in four years after its second-quarter profit more than doubled from last year. This, of course, is beating the street's forecast. The Suisse Bank, though, also warning the trade and geopolitical tensions along with changes in Central Bank policy, could hurt results for the rest of the year. Taking a look at the stock right now, it is higher in the premarket up more than a little more than 2-1/2 percent, excuse me.

Well, Nissan is installing its rear-door alert system in more of its vehicles. The company is going to add the feature to all of its four-door cars, SUVs, and pickups for the 2019 model year. The system lets drivers know when they have left something in the backseat like food, pets -- even kids. Shares of Nissan down about six percent so far, this year.

Well, Uber is shutting down its self-driving truck program auto. Remember, when they debuted this? Made such a big deal about it. Well, they now want to focus on their self-driving cars, instead. Uber acquired Anthony Levandowski's self-driving trucks startup about two years ago, but they later fired him after allegations from his previous employer, Alphabet's Waymo, that he stole trade secrets. That resulted in a lawsuit against Uber that was settled back in February. The move does not affect Uber freight -- that's an app that connects truck drivers with shippers.

And then there is this: MoviePass subscribers getting more frustrated. The CEO of MoviePass is now saying that upcoming big movie releases including "Christopher Robin" and "The Meg" are not available on the app. The all you can watch subscription service first crashed on Thursday, after its parent company ran out of cash, literally. Take a look at some of the tweets. A lot of good reaction. This one says, a live look at the MoviePass offices -- yes, image of a burning office. Here's a tweet with the screenshot of "Seinfeld" saying, MoviePass H.Q. currently, yes. Shares of MoviePass down nearly 100 percent this year. There you go.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Cheryl. Coming up, Lebron James accuses the president of the United States of dividing the nation. The NBA star's blunt new criticism of President Trump's stance on the NFL protest next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: NFL concussion settlement payouts hit half a billion dollars in less than two years. Jared Max is here with the story, Jared.

JARED MAX, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Dagen, good morning. Some good news here: Over 20,000 players have registered to receive potential benefits under the NFL's concussion settlement with former players. News broke yesterday, on the same day 24-year-old linebacker, Joshua Perry, announces retirement having suffered six concussions. Report release that shows the NFL is almost a full decade ahead in its projections for payouts. While the league had been criticized for dragging its heels on payments, now the NFL has distributed over $502 million. It had been projected the league would pay 400 million, the first decade, the settlement just went into effect January 2017. 521 players have been paid. Now, projected the league will pay $1.4 billion when all is said and done.

Christopher Seeger, Co-Lead Counsel for the players says, "We encourage all eligible former players to immediately sign up for a baseline assessment. They can take comfort in knowing that the compensation will be available for more than 60 years if they develop a qualifying condition. The settlement, fulfilling its promise to former NFL players and their families.

While the NFL's national anthem debate remains, so does conflict between sports and politics. While President Trump has been outspoken about his strong desire for NFL players to stand and honor the national anthem, his involvement has been questioned recently by some Cowboys Owner, Jerry Jones, called his involvement problematic. And last night, Lebron James said this:

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LEBRON JAMES, FORWARD, LOS ANGELES LAKERS: He's kind of using sport to, kind of, divide and that's something that I can't relate to because I know that sport was the first time I ever was around someone white. Sports has never been something that divide people, it's always something that brings someone together.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: These comments from Lebron James nothing shocking when we consider that he had said he wouldn't go to the White House even before they'd knew they go to championship.

MCDOWELL: Well, I'll just point out something that one of our viewers, John, tweeted as short while ago, as we were teasing the segment he said: "Actually, people in sports are the people dividing the country." President Trump is the one trying to heal it by calling the players out for divisive action, so Lebron James feels one way but at lot of other people in this country feel -- are on the other side of the field, so to speak.

MAX: This morning, Lea Gabrielle mentioned that who kneeled first and you think, wait a second, Colin Kaepernick kneeled first, Roger Goodell had he handled this in strong manner would President Trump even be involved in this conversation?

MCDOWELL: Right.

MORGAN ORTAGUS, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I think that this issue is just so polarizing. There's two sides. Each of them feels very strong emotions about their particular side. There's really no solution to this that's going to make everybody happy.

MCDOWELL: But I've listen today veterans like Joey Jones, he said give me that, give me my anthem -- a man who lost both of his legs serving this country, who walks on prosthetics and he has actually tried to reach out to Colin Kaepernick and started dialogue, and it eventually just shuts down and never gets anywhere. So, in terms of people who have -- are dug in on this, people on the players' side, people talk about President Trump being kind of intractable but it's the people on the other side who are equally dug in.

HILSENRATH: what should Goodell have done differently, you said, if he had acted strongly and it never would've come to this?

MAX: Well, I think he was scared. Everyone going through this for the first time; there's no guide on how to deal with this. What I think -- he became exposed does not necessarily a strong leader because he was unable to do this. What could he have done? I've said this on the air, I think, for a couple of years, I would not want to be in that position but I would certainly get the right people involved, the waffling back and forth is terrible. It's like you're driving in the car and you're on the road and the truth is, you're driving and you're lost and now everyone in the car knows you're lost, and now you're really in trouble. And that's where I think Roger Goodell is. Adam Silver, the Commissioner of the NBA dealt with this. He got the players involved; it was collectively bargained, you stand for the anthem. Roger Goodell, to me, hasn't, you know, hasn't done that properly.

MCDOWELL: Right. And the players -- you know, basketball, football, and the like, some of them keep talking about it.

MAX: Not easy situation to deal with.

MCDOWELL: Great to see you, Jared Max. His sports reports, Fox News Headlines 24/7, SiriusXM 115. Still ahead, that million-dollar (INAUDIBLE) you've got, may not be enough to retire on. New details on why that magic number might need a major boost to help you shine in your golden years or should you just spend your money now? Next hour on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Tuesday, July 31st. Your top stories at 7:00 a.m. Eastern.

END

Tesla is also reporting earnings, but the attention will be on its production numbers. The Federal Reserve board meets, but it’s not expected to raise interest rates.

Apple releases its earnings report while trade tensions loom.

Apple, the world’s most valuable company, is the last of the big tech companies to report earnings this quarter, scheduled for after the market closes on Tuesday. Apple has been largely insulated from many of the issues that have recently hit other tech companies, including   regulatory fines and   data misuse, and it is expected to report another round of big profits. Apple, however, may soon   face headwinds outside its control with an accelerating trade war between the United States and China. The company assembles many of its products, including iPhones, in China, while also depending on the country as its No. 3 market.

The European Union will issue an estimate of economic growth.

The European Union statistics agency will publish an estimate of its economic growth during the second quarter on Tuesday, shedding light on whether trade tensions are taking a toll on growth. President Trump’s tariffs on European steel and aluminum affect a relatively small sliver of the economy. But Mr. Trump’s   aggressive stance on trade may have unsettled European business executives and made them reluctant to invest, which would cut into gross domestic product.

The Fed will probably hold interest rates steady.

The Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates steady at the end of a two-day meeting on Wednesday. The Fed’s chairman, Jerome H. Powell, does not have a news conference scheduled, which means Fed watchers will have to wait to hear his opinion of President Trump’s   recent criticism of the Fed’s interest rate increases this year.

Tesla, facing supply and financial concerns, reports earnings.

Tesla reports its second-quarter earnings on Wednesday, and again the focus will be less on the expected loss than on any update on the number of Model 3 sedans the company has built. The electric-car maker is striving to be able to produce at least   5,000 Model 3s per week. The company’s chief executive, Elon Musk, has said that Tesla will be profitable in the second half of the year if it can reach that number. Tesla built that many in the final seven days of June, but it’s unclear if it has been able   to sustain that level of output. Analysts expect a loss of about $3.50 a share for the quarter. A year ago, the company reported a loss of $2.04 a share.

New vehicle sales are expected to have held steady in July.

On Wednesday, automakers will report new vehicle sales in July in the United States. The market researcher Cox Automotive said it expected sales of 1.4 million cars and light trucks, in line with the same period from a year ago. So far this year, new car sales are coming in   stronger than expected. Sales in the first half of the year are running ahead of the same period in 2017. But Cox said sales could soften in the second half, with both gasoline prices and interest rates on the rise, and some manufacturers reaching their limits on incentives and discounts.

European automakers may issue tariff warnings in their earnings reports.

The German automakersVolkswagen and BMW will report earnings this week, and they will most likely warn about the ill effects of the trade disputes involving the United States on their sales and profits. BMW, which reports on Thursday, faces stiff tariffs on cars it exports from a factory in South Carolina to China, which is retaliating against punitive measures enacted by the United States. Volkswagen,   which reports on Wednesday, has factories in Tennessee and Mexico and faces higher production costs because of American tariffs on imported steel and aluminum, as well as uncertainty about the future of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

Bank of England may raise interest rates. But maybe not.

The Bank of England’s monetary policy committee is widely expected raise the bank rate slightly to 0.75 percent from 0.5 percent on Thursday, but weak wage growth and inflation numbers have made the move less certain. A rise could lift the pound, but the currency is also under pressure from concerns around   Britain’s departure from the European Union.

The unemployment rate is expected to return to 3.9 percent.

On Friday, at 8:30 a.m., the Labor Department is scheduled to release its report on the nation’s hiring and unemployment for July. Wall Street analysts are looking for another strong month of growth with payrolls expected to expand by 190,000. The jobless rate is expected to decrease to 3.9 percent; it inched back up to 4 percent in Junebecause a surge of Americans decided to join the labor force, a sign that more people are optimistic about their employment prospects. Wage growth, though, has   continued to disappoint. Economists are expecting the average hourly wage to climb by 0.3 percent, which would keep the annual year-over-year increase level at 2.7 percent.

urn:contentItem:5M90-RH01-DYG0-5075-00000-00Apple rethinking self-driving car plans, shuts project parts2016-09-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:36ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. B7Apple rethinking self-driving car plans, shuts project partsFROM NEWS SERVICES

SAN FRANCISCO - Apple is rethinking what it plans to do about self-driving cars, just as other big tech companies appear ready to plow ahead with competing efforts. In a retrenchment of one of its most ambitious initiatives, Apple has shuttered parts of its self-driving car project and laid off dozens of employees, according to three people briefed on the move who were not allowed to speak about it publicly but told the New York Times. The job cuts are the latest sign of trouble with Apple's car initiative.

The company has added resources to the project - code-named Titan - over the last two years, but it has struggled to make progress on what some dubbed an iCar. And in July, the company brought in Bob Mansfield, a highly regarded Apple veteran, to take over the effort. The new direction apparently doesn't foreclose the possibility that Apple might someday build its own car, but it opens the door to partnering with other car companies. Apple employees were told that the layoffs were part of a "reboot" of the car project, the people briefed on it said. Apple had no official comment and has consistently declined to confirm its automotive ambitions. But Elon Musk, the chief executive of electric-car maker Tesla, has said that Apple has hired hundreds of engineers, including some from Tesla, to work on an automotive project. Local officials in the San Francisco Bay Area say Apple contacted them last year about using a former naval base that's been converted into an automotive testing ground. The New York Times and Bloomberg News have reported that Apple's initial efforts to design its own car have suffered from management turnover and technical delays. Industry experts say building a car is an incredibly complex challenge for any company, even one with the engineering prowess of Apple. Automobile manufacture also poses more regulatory and legal issues than building an iPhone or a computer. But the tech industry has increasingly ventured into the automotive sector, where Apple, Google, and other firms are competing to develop software that can help manage - at least - the information and entertainment systems inside today's vehicles. Google has made no secret that it's also working on self-driving technology, but it says that it is more likely to partner with an established automaker. Automakers such as Ford, General Motors, and FiatChrysler have all said they expect to put a number of self-driving vehicles on the road in five years or less. As for Apple, under Mr. Mansfield, the company changed the focus of the car project, shifting from an emphasis on designing and producing an automobile to building out the underlying technology for an autonomous vehicle. Electric cars rely not on the internal combustion engine, but technologies more prevalent in the consumer electronics world: batteries, sensors, and software. In addition, self-driving cars could change the traditional notions of public transportation and car ownership. Apple pulled in staff members from other divisions and hired experts, growing to more than 1,000 employees in about 18 months. But as the project grew rapidly, it encountered a number of problems, and people working on it struggled to explain what Apple could bring to a self-driving car that other companies could not, according to the people briefed on the project.

urn:contentItem:5TKJ-8281-JCJY-G2V9-00000-00Apple rings up record sales as Facebook flails2018-10-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:36ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:1Apple rings up record sales as Facebook flailsDanny Fortson

Apple is expected to ride sales of its new £1,000 smartphones to record profits this week, while Facebook seeks to regain its footing in the wake of scandals, stalling growth and a tanking share price.

Facebook is due to publish its performance for the three months to September on Tuesday, with Apple scheduled to announce full-year figures on Thursday.

Wall Street expects the iPhone maker to the buck the trend of disappointing results from big tech rivals such as Amazon and Alphabet, Google's parent company.

The $1 trillion (£780bn) company last month released a new line of iPhone X handsets, ranging in price from £999 to £1,450.

Analysts at Wedbush Securities predicted the stock, which closed on Friday at $216.30, would hit $310, valuing the company at $1.5trn. It has pencilled in a surge to $58bn in profit on sales of $263bn, which would both be records for the California-based giant.

Its previous best annual results came in 2016 when it earned $53bn, before dipping last year to $48bn. The expected jump could come due to pent-up demand from hundreds of millions of iPhone users waiting to swap old models for higher-priced, more profitable handsets, and the company's surging services business, which includes the App Store and music streaming.

By contrast, Facebook is flailing. Its share price has plunged by a third since it revealed in August that growth had begun to slow.

Buffeted by scandal, regulatory fines and investigations into election meddling, the stock closed on Friday at $145.37, valuing the company at $419bn - a $140bn drop from the heights of three months ago.

Tim Cook, Apple's chief executive, has joined in the criticism of Facebook.

In a speech in Brussels, he bashed social media companies for harvesting data to target ads with "military efficiency" to "enrich" themselves at the cost of users' privacy.

Analysts forecast $13.8bn in sales at Facebook, which would be a one-third jump against the same period last year. Analysts expect profit, however, to come in at $4.3bn - a 10% drop - as the social media platform ploughs more money into technology and staff to weed out bad content.
